comments.commentBody: Go, Celtics!

So now it is time for the refs 2 step it up and call the real game as they see it and not be manipulated by the coaches, as the series is tied and up for graps. Less whining from Boston tonight but as you see they still whine every chance they get even when it is an obvious foul-example Wallace...the Lakers Odom outplayed by Davis, Robinson outplayed the entire Laker second unit, and Fisher tonight...If the Lakers bench continue not too show up and Odom is ghost again and again on offense & defense the C's win this series. We need as fans too see the real series play out from here, and the refs need too do their job, and step up and make the calls when necessary where necessary no matter the venue. Desperate Boston wins tonight, the real challenge is game-5, doubt if Lakers play the same 4th quarter if tight game heading into the 4th quarter game 5. Boston needs game 5 or the series is over! Will need too play desperate again-

Love it when you get a word from crosses and it's one you've never heard of. That was the case with RATITE. Had to look it up.

A good test tonight, for a long time I had PEAU at the end of the name, before I realized that it was CHITS rather than CHIPS going down. Then everything fell into place pretty quickly. I trust I was not the only one to make this initial error.
It's funny to me that it is recommended to read a book with a child on your lap. I was always jealous of the way my father disappeared into books all the time. It's just the toys that change.

I have to agree with Lori, #24. I am a modern person who uses technology at work and home, but what is so amazingly important that people have to check some device constantly? For example, I have seen parents checking them during parent-teacher night presentations at my children's school (while teacher was speaking), a friend texting while our families with children were taking a hike through the woods, while walking, and yes, audience members using them during a music concert. I just don't see the need for this stuff. And it is rude, to boot.

"...a mother and blogger in Wilmette, Ill., said she had no idea how what she calls her “addiction to e-mail and social media Web sites” was bothering her children..."

Do parents actually not know that children require a lot of attention? And that the attention they pay their children is called "parenting"? And these are the educated parents.

Those poor children.
Look at the data, see that the men talk to the children almost half as much as the women do!  Interesting.

Hello,

As I read this this early morning, I was satisfied that "competition" of the tech a parent is utilizing in the presence of a child was placed forward for discussion to the audience of the NYT.

It also jogged my memory that I did not include these aspects of the adult and child and tech in my list over on the comment section of "Your Brain on Computers, Hooked on Gadgets, and Paying a Mental Price" 6 June 2010. Because it has and is discussed as to the role I as a parent have with my teen. I value my child's input.

Also it jogged my memory of a jaunt for a lovely Saturday lunch at a casual deli where I and my partner became infuriated with one another's assessment of what was happening at a table aside us .. .. a family arrives; a dad, a mum, a toddler with beginning vocab, a 7/8 month old and a grandma-ma. Buckle the toddler into the booster, kaplunk the car seat carrier holding baby onto the wooden table, the dad off to order, the grandma-ma seeming totally displaced [as it appeared she had just arrived for a visit and that this was an outing to be relished] and the mum evaporated into texting on a smartphone and scrolling on and on and on. Not looking up for a glance as to her surrounds.

My opinion, what happened to 20 minutes of sharing food, that ancient connective need of us humans, the phone could just be left for the brief moment.

My partner's opinion, the mum had no other time for uninterrupted use of the smartphone.

I know parenting often feels breathless in time for one's self, but ....

Now what irks me to nearly becoming mad is people backing out of their parking spot with the mobile already at their ear. How has technology made us feel secure and safe that we can back out, place a call on a cell, watch for pedestrians, traffic, have passengers conversations in the auto, let alone music on or a dvd and be S..A..F..E ?

Don't misunderstand, I have to limit myself to tech, the monitors memorize me as to - Oh ! The Places We Can Go. {Apology offered Dr Suess) Yet, I believe with conviction I value the human scape more than the tech gadgets and this is what makes it all work in a conducive way for my life and my family's life. I hope in reflection of my life this will be considered as my having been wise.

kind wishes,
Sigolene
Personal technology is presenting us with a social dividing line in society. Those that can empathize and those that can not. It tells a sad story of ourselves.

Do the techy parents who constantly blog and Twitter and Flickr and text only remember the milestones of their children through those tools? Do they remeember the actual moment minus the technology?

As for the socieconomic question -- once you get into the wealth aspect, how many of those kids have/had direct interaction with their parents vs. hired attendants to begin with?

I find it shocking and sad when mothers and fathers talk on Bluetooth-type devices while carrying small children and babies in their arms. It appears that they are speaking to the child, but it turns out they are talking to someone else, who is not visible. Aside from being incredibly rude to the baby, what lessons will the child receive about communication? Yes, I too believe that social disorders may well be the result of this behavior.

Technology is here to stay, but we need to learn how to use it instead of letting it rule us.

Look around at moms pushing aircraft carrier prams containing large blobs of kids who should be walking and running and talking to the mom. But she is busy talking on a cell or texting furiously. The kid's face tell the story: "I'm forgotten..." When they get older, they will embrace their own technologies with the same addiction, then all will wonder what went wrong.

The article mentions parents texting while driving with their children in the car.  Child development aside, any parent who texts while driving their children should count themselves lucky if they only kill themselves, and not their kids or someone else's kids.

I find the opening example silly. Two and a half year olds exhibit that behavior whether or not the parent is using an electronic device. You'll get the 'mama, mama, hi mama! hi mama, mama, mama, mama, hi mama, hi mama, mama MAMA, MAMA, HI MOM' potentially at any time. In fact it happened to me today, and I was not texting (I am not a texter), nor using any other electronic device. Two and a half year olds like to be the center of the universe. It is healthy for them to learn that they don't demand their parents' undivided attention at will and to help them develop a sense that other people do in fact exist.

Now that isn't to say that there may be parents out there who are far too plugged into their electronic devices, all day, and need to quit and give their children their true attention at least at some points during the day but the article gives the wrong impression. It is okay, actually healthy and important, to learn that their parents are not their play things.

Oh, by the way, to a small child, there is only quantity of time. The person who spends the most time with the child is who they bond with, be it for better or worse.

'Quality time' is some made up concept to make working parents feel better.

Sorry.

Mothers tuning out their kids is nothing new.  I'm 58 years old and remember my mother constantly doing it to me and my brothers and sisters.  It was an art form with her.  You could be yelling at the top of your lungs for her attention and she wouldn't hear it.

how could Mr. Greene be a plant.  So what if someone gave him the 10,000.  No one forced the voters hands.  Mr. Greene won, luck, but either way, he won.  He they want him to step down they need to refund his check x 20.
With honor and humility President Obama meets with the families and they individually thank him for his concern and reassurance. Why would the right-wing smear merchants mock this occasion?
It seems BP wanted to drill this hole in 500 feet of water, but the feds nixed it.  Hope the NYT  digs into this to cast light on the veracity.

Shenani-goats like this are not as rare as one might think: it's not unusual for  interest groups to pay for robo-calls the evening prior to an election suggesting that voters in a specific target group "cross over" and vote for a particular candidate in order to undermine the other party. However, this situation in SC, which extends beyond Greene to other Democratic candidates in state and US House races, seems to be bordering on -- dare I say it? -- conspiracy?

I don't get the problem.  There were two unknowns in the primary.  The one with the broader ethnic base won.  If he's a stooge, he is; too bad his opponent didn't bother to do any research or take his own candidacy all that seriously.  Btw, elbowing Greene out of the race is not going to endear the other guy (what's his name again?) to the voters,  Better just chalk this up to experience.
Glad that Obama finally found time to meet with the victims' families in the midst of his celebrity celebrations.
Why don't we just tell Boehner that it's tanning oil that's spilling into the gulf. He'd go there and slather it on like there were no tomorrow.
Hopefully Carly has learned that for the rest of her political life, every second is open mike night.

You know the Republicans are going to have trouble playing all sides of this "Smaller Government/ Where's the Government / Individual and Corporate Responsibility sans Regulation " cognitive dissonance in their heads.
